title: 107_hr2787
content:
SECTION 1. REFERENCE. This Act amends sections of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. SEC. 2. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. Congress finds that two-thirds of mothers with children under 6 years old are in the workforce, over 10 percent of young children have disabilities (with higher rates in low-income communities), and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates early intervention and special education preschool services for children with disabilities. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates special education preschool services for children with disabilities to be delivered in a natural environment with their nondisabled peers. The availability of infant care, care for special needs children, and care during nonstandard hours is limited, especially in low-income communities. The availability of child care during nonstandard hours is limited, especially in low-income communities. Children with disabilities or special health care needs face barriers in accessing child care programs due to myths, stereotypes, and lack of staff training. The purpose of this Act is to increase the supply of quality child care for children with disabilities. SEC. 3. APPLICATION AND PLAN.

Amends Section 658E(c) (42 U.S.C. 9858c(c)) to include families with children with disabilities.

SEC. 4. ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF CHILD CARE. Section 658G (42 U.S.C. 9858e) is amended to include activities for children with disabilities, requiring states to allocate at least 5 percent of funds for this purpose. States receiving funds for child care services must allocate at least 5 percent for activities to improve child care for children with disabilities, including training and technical assistance. States receiving funds for child care services must allocate at least 5 percent for activities to improve child care for children with disabilities, including training and technical assistance for child care providers, licensing agencies, and parents to collaborate effectively. State licensing agencies and parents are advised to collaborate on implementing the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Technical assistance is provided to child care providers to better include children with disabilities. Technical assistance is provided to family home and center child care providers to include children with disabilities. Training is also offered on the use of assistive technology for children with special needs and disabilities, as well as leadership skills development for child care facility directors. Training is provided for child care facility directors to develop leadership skills in financial, program, parent education, and community development for inclusive child care programs. Assistance is also given to child care resource agencies on Americans with Disabilities Act compliance. Training for child care facility directors includes developing leadership skills in financial, program, parent education, and community development. Assistance is provided to child care resource agencies on compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. Grants are available for scholarships for child care staff working with children with disabilities. Grants are provided for scholarships and salary increases for child care staff to obtain degrees or training in child development. Grants are available to increase salaries of child care staff with degrees or training in child development and to retain qualified providers in the field. Low-interest loans are also provided for certain child care programs. The Secretary can provide grants and low-interest loans to public agencies and nonprofit organizations for projects that enhance child care availability, including inclusive programs, infant care, and evening/weekend care. SEC. 5. REPORTS. Amends Section 658K(a)(1)(B)(iii) by adding "disability status" to the reporting requirements. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Section 658P (42 U.S.C. 9858n) is amended to include definitions for "child with a disability" and "inclusive child care program" as per the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The term "inclusive child care program" is defined as a program that serves both children with disabilities and children without disabilities together, with no more than 50 percent of the children enrolled being children with disabilities.
